name: Abert's Squirrel
region: Southwestern US and northern Mexico (Colorado, Utah, Arizona, New Mexico, extending to Chihuahua and Durango)
habitat: Mature ponderosa pine forests
description: Easily identified by its distinctive ear tufts extending 2-3 cm upward, this tassel-eared squirrel can consume seeds from up to 75 ponderosa pine cones in a single day and shows remarkable dietary flexibility by safely consuming mushrooms that are deadly to humans.

name: Agile Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California
habitat: Shrubby areas with lighter soils
description: A nimble desert hopper that evolved alongside Ord's kangaroo rat from a common ancestor, preferring shrubby terrain where it outcompetes its close relative Stephens's kangaroo rat through superior habitat selection.

name: Alaska Marmot
region: Brooks Range and northern Alaska
habitat: Alpine tundra, rocky mountain slopes and scree fields near lakes
description: This stocky rodent hibernates for up to eight months annually, dropping its body temperature to near freezing while its heart rate plummets—a survival strategy so extreme it awakens only every three to four weeks to urinate. Despite their remote Arctic habitat, Alaska marmots live in colonies of up to 50, using coordinated sentry duty to warn of golden eagles and grizzly bears.

name: Allen's Chipmunk
region: Western US (California, Oregon, Nevada)
habitat: Old-growth coniferous forests and Sierra Nevada mountains
description: This arboreal chipmunk nests as high as 88 feet above ground and is the only chipmunk species that collects and stores the seeds it eats, along with fungi that comprise up to 99% of its diet in virgin forests.

name: Alpine Chipmunk
region: High Sierra Nevada, California
habitat: Alpine zone at high elevations
description: This diminutive alpine dweller weighs a mere 27-45 grams yet survives at elevations up to 12,800 feet, hibernating for five months and frequently awakening to snack during winter's harshest months.

name: American Beaver
region: Continental US, Canada, southern Alaska, northern Mexico
habitat: Lakes, streams, rivers, and wetlands in boreal and temperate forests
description: An aquatic engineer capable of constructing dams over half a mile long and staying submerged for up to 15 minutes, this rodent nearly drove itself to extinction through relentless trapping but has made a remarkable comeback across North America.

name: American Red Squirrel
region: Canada, Alaska, Rocky Mountains, Northern Eastern US
habitat: Coniferous forests and mixed woodlands
description: A pint-sized hoarder that can accumulate cone scales in middens up to 40 feet across, these territorial squirrels defend their cache year-round and mate with 4 to 16 partners in a single day during breeding season.

name: Arctic Ground Squirrel
region: Arctic Alaska, Northern Canada, Siberia
habitat: Arctic tundra, mountain slopes, river flats, sandy soil burrows
description: This Arctic hibernator can reduce its body temperature to −3°C (27°F) and slow its heart rate to one beat per minute, with blood that remains liquid while frozen—a phenomenon scientists hope could revolutionize organ transplant preservation. During hibernation from August to April, its brain connections dissolve only to mysteriously regrow upon waking.

name: Arizona Gray Squirrel
region: Eastern Arizona, northern Mexico
habitat: Mountain canyons and riparian forests at mid-elevations
description: More closely related to fox squirrels despite its gray appearance, this canyon dweller sports a distinctive red and black striped tail and breeds only when flower blooms provide enough energy to sustain the costly demands of reproduction.

name: Arizona Pocket Mouse
region: Sonoran Desert (Arizona)
habitat: Sonoran Desert scrubland
description: A nocturnal desert specialist that stuffs seeds into oversized cheek pouches and ferries them back to underground burrows for storage. Its smooth, thinly-furred tail and tan-to-orange coloring provide perfect camouflage in the harsh Arizona landscape.

name: Attwater's Pocket Gopher
region: Texas Coastal Bend
habitat: Coastal grasslands and prairies
description: A burrowing rodent named after English naturalist Henry Philemon Attwater, this underground specialist uses its powerful claws to excavate extensive tunnel networks through the Texas coastal landscape in search of roots and tubers.

name: Bailey's Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (California, Arizona, New Mexico) and Northwestern Mexico
habitat: Desert shrublands and arid regions
description: This nocturnal desert dweller is the only animal on Earth capable of digesting the toxic wax found in jojoba nuts, allowing it to feast on seeds that poison nearly every other mammal. A master hoarder, it carries seeds in fur-lined cheek pouches back to its burrow, keeping them perfectly dry.

name: Baird's Pocket Gopher
region: Eastern Texas, Western Louisiana, Eastern Oklahoma, Southwestern Arkansas
habitat: Underground burrows in Gulf Coastal Plains with sandy or loamy soil
description: A cylindrical burrower that constructs complex tunnel systems up to 180 cm long while foraging underground, using specialized cheek pouches to transport food back to its elaborate winter chambers complete with nesting areas and food storage.

name: Baja Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California, Baja California, Gulf of California islands
habitat: Arid scrublands and desert regions
description: A diminutive desert dweller with specialized cheek pouches for carrying seeds across the arid southwestern landscape. One subspecies, the Montserrat Island pocket mouse, vanished from existence in 1975.

name: Banner-tailed Kangaroo Rat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas) and Mexico
habitat: Desert grassland with scattered shrubs
description: A nocturnal hopper with a distinctive black-and-white banner tail that constructs elaborate burrow systems with 3-meter mounds, accumulating massive seed caches in underground chambers and emerging only at dusk to forage for two hours before returning home.

name: Belding's Ground Squirrel
region: Northwestern US (Oregon, Washington, California, Idaho, Nevada, Utah)
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, sagebrush flats
description: These industrious rodents spend up to 40% of their summer eating to build fat reserves for hibernation, then recognize their relatives by comparing scents from specialized glands. Females produce piercing alarm calls to warn kin of predators while remaining silent when fleeing from terrestrial threats.

name: Big-eared Kangaroo Rat
region: Central California (San Benito and Monterey counties)
habitat: Chaparral
description: Distinguished by its unusually large ears relative to body size, this tiny rodent uses its oversized auditory organs to detect predators and navigate the chaparral scrublands of central California. Despite its small stature, it can leap several feet in a single bound using powerful hind legs.

name: Black-tailed Prairie Dog
region: Great Plains, US-Canada border to US-Mexico border
habitat: Shortgrass and mixed-grass prairie, sagebrush steppe
description: These highly social rodents form massive underground cities with sophisticated vocal communication systems that can describe specific predators, their size, and approach speed. A single prairie dog town in Texas once covered 25,000 square miles and contained 400 million individuals.

name: Botta's Pocket Gopher
region: Western North America from California to Texas
habitat: Woodlands, chaparral, scrubland, and agricultural areas
description: A tireless underground miner that can excavate up to 28 tons of soil per hectare annually, spending 90% of its life in burrows and reaching depths of up to 5 feet. Its teeth are specially adapted for digging, allowing it to thrive in soils ranging from loose sand to packed clay.

name: California Chipmunk
region: Southern California and Baja California
habitat: Chaparral and scrubland
description: A nimble burrower of California's chaparral, this small rodent darts through scrubland with remarkable agility despite weighing less than an ounce. Known for its striped back and cheek pouches, it stashes seeds and nuts for survival through lean seasons.

name: California Ground Squirrel
region: Western US (Oregon, California, Washington, northwestern Nevada) and Baja California Peninsula
habitat: Burrows in gardens, parks, and open areas with ornamental plants
description: This cunning burrower has evolved extraordinary defenses against rattlesnakes, including the ability to super-heat its tail and wave it to signal danger—a tactic that successfully deters snake attacks in 67% of encounters. Some populations have even developed partial resistance to rattlesnake venom as adults.

name: California Kangaroo Rat
region: Northern California and southern Oregon
habitat: Grasslands and foothills from Sierra Nevada to Cascade Mountains
description: This 312mm rodent possesses a distinctive white-tipped tail with black stripes and is so well-adapted to harsh environments that it thrives where few humans dare to venture. Unlike common rats, it never scavenges human food and carries no dangerous pathogens, making it an ideal neighbor in inhospitable terrain.

name: California Pocket Mouse
region: California and Northern Baja California
habitat: Chaparral and woodlands
description: A nocturnal seed hoarder equipped with external cheek pouches, this tiny rodent weighs less than an ounce yet stores seeds across its territory. Despite being widespread across central and southern California, its habitat continues to shrink due to climate change and urban development.

name: Camas Pocket Gopher
region: Willamette Valley, northwestern Oregon
habitat: Clay-rich grasslands, shrublands, and agricultural fields
description: The largest of its genus, this underground burrower uses prominent buck teeth to excavate tunnels exceeding 240 meters in hard clay soil, and constructs unique vertical chimney mounds for ventilation using Bernoulli's principle.

name: Cascade Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel
region: Cascade Mountains of Washington and British Columbia
habitat: Mountain forests and meadows
description: Born ectothermic but rapidly developing internal heat regulation, this ground squirrel covers an impressive 5 kilometers daily—traveling at a maximum aerobic speed of 3.63 m/s to outrun predators. Its distinctive alarm calls are so unique they can be identified with 100% accuracy, making this the largest of its three-species genus unmistakable to fellow squirrels.

name: Chihuahuan Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Texas, New Mexico) and Mexico
habitat: Desert scrubland with sandy soil
description: A nocturnal desert dweller weighing just 15-23 grams that constructs elaborate multi-chambered burrows with numerous hidden exits. This seed-hoarding rodent can enter torpor during winter months and was only recognized as a distinct species in 1996 through DNA analysis.

name: Chisel-toothed Kangaroo Rat
region: Great Basin and High Desert (Nevada, Utah, California, Oregon, Arizona, Idaho)
habitat: Arid desert shrubland with saltbush, gravelly soils at moderate to high elevations
description: This tiny desert specialist has evolved chisel-shaped incisors to scrape salt crystals off toxic saltbush leaves, then stores up to 250 grams of leaves in its burrows and obtains all its water from the vegetation—a unique survival strategy among kangaroo rats.

name: Cliff Chipmunk
region: Western US (Arizona to Colorado) and Mexico
habitat: Cliff walls and boulder fields in pinyon-juniper woodlands
description: A gravity-defying acrobat that scales sheer cliff faces with ease, this tiny 2.5-ounce rodent forgoes body fat storage and instead meticulously hoards food for winter survival. Remarkably long-lived for its size, it can reach over 12 years of age.

name: Colorado Chipmunk
region: Colorado, Utah, Arizona, New Mexico
habitat: Coniferous forests and montane woodlands at high elevation
description: The largest chipmunk of the Colorado Front Range, this tiny rodent can weigh up to 62 grams yet fiercely defends its territory with vocalizations and caches enough seeds and berries to survive harsh mountain winters above 4,900 feet in elevation.

name: Columbia Plateau Pocket Mouse
region: Great Basin, Pacific Northwest, and adjacent western US from British Columbia to Arizona
habitat: Arid shrublands, sagebrush steppes, and pinyon-juniper woodlands
description: A master seed hoarder that requires 870 to 1,000 seeds daily and can locate buried caches from underground using mysterious sensory abilities. This nocturnal rodent enters torpor during harsh seasons to conserve energy, slowing its metabolism to mere kilocalories per day.

name: Columbian Ground Squirrel
region: Rocky Mountains and high plains from Alberta and British Columbia south through Montana, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, grasslands, and mountain slopes at 700–8,000 feet elevation
description: This burrowing rodent hibernates for 8–9 months per year and emerges emaciated in spring, with mothers' milk increasing calcium concentration by 134% to fuel their young before the first hibernation. Known for greeting each other with kissing behavior and spending more time standing at attention than any other above-ground activity.

name: Coulee Chipmunk
region: Central Washington (Channeled Scablands)
habitat: Scablands and arid shrublands
description: A cryptic chipmunk species once mistaken for its close relatives, distinguished by its distinctly grayer coloration and ability to coexist in the same habitat as multiple other chipmunk species.

name: Dark Kangaroo Mouse
region: Western US (Oregon, California, Nevada, Idaho, Utah)
habitat: Loose sand and gravels in Upper Sonoran life zone
description: This tiny hopper weighs just 13 grams but stores fat in its tail like a camel, growing it thick before winter hibernation and thin again in spring—a unique adaptation among North American small mammals. Perfectly adapted to desert life, it never needs to drink water, instead extracting all moisture from seeds it carries in cheek pouches back to its burrow.

name: Delmarva Fox Squirrel
region: Eastern Shore of Maryland and Virginia, historically Delmarva Peninsula
habitat: Mature hardwood and pine forests with open understory
description: Once hunted to near extinction with only 10% of its population remaining, this frosty silver squirrel has made a remarkable comeback through dedicated reintroduction efforts. A nimble tree-dweller reaching up to 30 inches in length, it can survive on acorns, hickory nuts, and pine cones found only in forest habitats with open space to forage.

name: Desert Kangaroo Rat
region: Southwestern US deserts (Death Valley, Great Basin, Mojave, Sonoran)
habitat: Sandy desert dunes with sparse vegetation
description: A master of desert survival, this nimble rodent can go 2-3 weeks without drinking water by extracting moisture from seeds and its own metabolism. When threatened by snakes, it fearlessly drums its feet and kicks sand to warn predators it's aware of their presence.

name: Desert Pocket Gopher
region: Southwest US (Texas, New Mexico) and northern Mexico (Chihuahua)
habitat: Sandy riverbanks and loose soil near the Rio Grande Valley and irrigation canals
description: A powerful burrower with massive clawed forelimbs, this rodent causes more soil disturbance than other gopher species and can reshape desert landscapes through its relentless digging. Found only in a narrow strip along the Rio Grande, its isolated populations make it one of North America's most geographically restricted pocket gophers.

name: Desert Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US and northern Mexico
habitat: Arid desert with sparse vegetation, sandy washes, and desert scrub
description: A nocturnal desert dweller that can chew through hard-crusted soil to burrow and stores seeds in hidden caches throughout its territory. Despite living in harsh, arid environments, this tiny mouse survives on seeds alone and requires no additional water beyond its food.

name: Douglas Squirrel
region: Pacific Northwest to central California
habitat: Coniferous forests, old-growth and mature second-growth
description: A vocal forest dweller that accumulates massive cone-scale middens up to several meters across through generations of feeding, earning the Native American name 'Pillillooeet' from its characteristic alarm call. Weighing just 150-300 grams, it nonetheless claims territorial dominance over 10,000 square meters of forest during winter months.

name: Dulzura Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California, Colorado Desert, and northwestern Mexico (Baja California)
habitat: Sandy and gravelly soils in semi-desert, dry grassland, scrub, and coastal chaparral
description: A nocturnal hopper that can reach densities of up to 45 animals per hectare, propelling itself exclusively on powerful hind legs while using its long tail as a stabilizer. This seed-hoarder stuffs its cheek pouches with food and can live in burrows with multiple hidden entrances, emerging only a few hours each night.

name: Eastern Chipmunk
region: Eastern North America and southern Canada
habitat: Deciduous woodlands and urban parks with rocky areas and brush
description: This striped burrower can trill at 130 vibrations per minute and is the only living member of its genus, measuring just 12 inches long but capable of constructing elaborate underground tunnel systems with multiple entrances.

name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
region: Eastern and Midwestern US, Southern Canada
habitat: Mature oak-hickory hardwood forests, urban parks and gardens
description: A master hoarder that creates thousands of food caches annually using precise spatial memory, yet forgets enough to accidentally plant entire forests. This acrobat can descend trees head-first by rotating its hind feet backward, and melanistic individuals exhibit 18% reduced heat loss compared to their gray cousins.

name: Fox Squirrel
region: Eastern US, Great Plains, southern Canadian provinces
habitat: Open forest patches with oak, hickory, and pine trees; urban and suburban areas
description: North America's largest tree squirrel, capable of leaping 15 feet horizontally and free-falling 20 feet or more while landing gracefully on tree limbs. Known for their impressive vocabulary of clucking sounds and ability to cache thousands of nuts for winter survival.

name: Franklin's Ground Squirrel
region: Northern Great Plains and Midwest (Alberta to Indiana)
habitat: Tallgrass prairies with dense vegetation
description: An omnivorous ground squirrel that hibernates for eight months a year and can consume prey as large as fully-grown mallards, weighing up to 950 grams by fall despite starting spring at just 370 grams.

name: Fresno Kangaroo Rat
region: San Joaquin Valley, California
habitat: Alkaline grasslands, saltbush scrub, and foothill shrublands
description: The smallest kangaroo rat in its genus, this nocturnal rodent is three times less active under moonlight and uses powerful hind limbs to bound across the valley floor like its larger marsupial namesake. Once widespread across the San Joaquin Valley, its range has shrunk to fragmented patches totaling just 20,000 square kilometers due to agricultural development.

name: Giant Kangaroo Rat
region: Central California (San Joaquin Valley region)
habitat: Dry, sandy grasslands
description: The largest of over 20 kangaroo rat species, this master communicator drums its feet at up to 18 beats per second to warn of danger and attract mates. Once found across vast grasslands, it now survives in less than 2% of its original range.

name: Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel
region: Rocky Mountains and western North America
habitat: Coniferous forests, meadows, and sagebrush with rocky areas
description: Distinguished by its striking reddish mantle across the shoulders and white-bordered black stripes along its back, this squirrel can create burrows up to 100 feet long and stores enough food to sustain itself through hibernation lasting several months.

name: Gray-collared Chipmunk
region: Arizona and New Mexico
habitat: Mountain coniferous forests, ponderosa pine and spruce-fir forests
description: A skilled climber with a distinctive gray face and collar, this chipmunk caches food in hidden holes and can sustain itself through winter on stored acorns and seeds without fully hibernating. Population density can quadruple from spring to late summer, peaking at 12 individuals per hectare.

name: Gray-footed Chipmunk
region: Southwestern US (New Mexico, West Texas)
habitat: Temperate mountain forests with mixed oak, pine, and fir trees
description: A nimble rock-dweller of the southwestern mountains that stuffs its cheeks with acorns, pine seeds, and insects before retreating into rocky crevices. Young chipmunks reach full size by October after a single annual breeding cycle, with females producing up to four offspring.

name: Groundhog
region: Eastern United States, Canada, Alaska
habitat: Woodlands, grasslands, open fields, and woodland edges
description: A master excavator capable of removing 640 pounds of soil from a single burrow, this rodent's incisors grow 1.5 millimeters weekly and are worn down at the same rate through constant gnawing. Despite its stocky appearance, it can climb trees and swim with surprising agility when escaping predators.

name: Gulf Coast Kangaroo Rat
region: Southeastern Texas and coastal islands
habitat: Sandy dunes and sparse mesquite savannah
description: This nocturnal desert dweller uses its oversized cheek pouches to transport seeds back to its burrow, and can be distinguished from similar species by its notably shorter, uncrested tail and coarser fur.

name: Gunnison's Prairie Dog
region: Four Corners region (Arizona, New Mexico, Utah, Colorado)
habitat: High desert grasslands, sagebrush meadows, 6,000–10,000 feet elevation
description: These burrowing rodents possess one of the most advanced natural languages in the animal kingdom, with up to 11 distinct warning calls that can be heard nearly a mile away and last up to 30 minutes. Uniquely among prairie dogs, Gunnison's species has 40 chromosomes instead of 50, making them chromosomally distinct from all other prairie dog species.

name: Hall's Pocket Gopher
region: Western US (Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska)
habitat: Grasslands and prairie regions
description: A genetically distinct burrowing rodent that was long mistaken for other pocket gopher species until chromosomal evidence revealed it as a separate lineage with no gene flow to its closest relatives. Two subspecies inhabit different regions, with the smaller Nebraska population named after renowned mammalogist Eugene Raymond Hall.

name: Harris's Antelope Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico) and Sonora, Mexico
habitat: Sonoran Desert and arid scrubland
description: A heat-defying desert dweller that holds its tail over its back like a parasol and spreads-eagles against the ground to dump excess body heat in the scorching Sonoran Desert. Despite weighing only 4–5 ounces, this pint-sized squirrel maintains a blazing body temperature of 97–107°F and hunts small rodents and carrion alongside its diet of cacti and mesquite beans.

name: Heermann's Kangaroo Rat
region: California, from Lake Tahoe to Point Conception
habitat: Coastal plains and ridges with shallow soil, up to 3,000 feet elevation
description: This broad-faced nocturnal rodent spends up to 23 hours per day in underground burrows, emerging only at night to forage for seeds and insects. Capable of hopping up to 30 inches in a single bound using its distinctive tail for balance.

name: Hispid Pocket Mouse
region: Great Plains from North Dakota to central Mexico
habitat: Sandy upland grasslands with sparse vegetation and bare ground patches
description: One of the largest pocket mice, this bristly-furred forager is notable for its mound-building behavior around burrow entrances, similar to pocket gophers but far smaller. Capable of bearing two or more litters per year, it thrives in the sparse, sandy soils of the Great Plains.

name: Hoary Marmot
region: Northwestern North America, Alaska to Washington/Idaho
habitat: Alpine meadows and rocky terrain above tree line, sea level to 8,200 feet elevation
description: The largest North American ground squirrel, weighing up to 13.5 pounds in autumn—nearly double its spring weight—and famous for its high-pitched warning whistle that alerts entire colonies to danger from up to 36 individuals strong.

name: Hopi Chipmunk
region: Southwestern US (Colorado, Utah, Arizona)
habitat: Rocky pinyon-juniper forests and canyon country
description: A naturally timid acrobat of the canyon rocks, weighing just 52-62 grams yet capable of navigating sheer cliff faces with incredible sure-footedness. Even when raised in captivity, these chipmunks never become tame, always maintaining their wild wariness as they zip between boulders watching for hawks.

name: Humboldt's Flying Squirrel
region: Pacific Coast (British Columbia to Southern California)
habitat: Coniferous and mixed coniferous forests
description: A strictly nocturnal glider that can traverse between trees with remarkable agility, though it awkwardly stumbles on the ground. Under ultraviolet light, this squirrel's fur glows an eerie pink—a phenomenon whose true purpose remains mysteriously debated among scientists.

name: Idaho Pocket Gopher
region: Northwestern US (Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Utah)
habitat: Savannas, shrublands, and grasslands
description: A solitary burrowing rodent weighing less than 3.2 ounces that remains active year-round, excavating and storing soil in its own personal underground tunnel system. Its slender skull and long baculum bone make it distinctly adapted for a subterranean lifestyle.

name: Knox Jones's Pocket Gopher
region: Central western Texas and southeastern New Mexico
habitat: Deep sandy soils in arid regions
description: A master burrower with oversized clawed forelimbs, this diminutive rodent weighs less than a deck of cards yet was only recognized as its own species in 1989 after genetic testing proved it distinct from its nearly identical cousin. Its preference for sandy soils over harder earth made it invisible to science for decades.

name: Least Chipmunk
region: Western North America from New Mexico to Canada, including Michigan and Wisconsin
habitat: Sagebrush, coniferous woodlands, alpine meadows, and tundra edges
description: The smallest chipmunk species and most widespread across North America, measuring just 6-10 inches long. Survives harsh winters by entering torpor rather than hibernating, waking to munch on cached food stored deep in burrows.

name: Little Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah), Baja California, and Sonora
habitat: Arid and semiarid grasslands with sagebrush and scrubby vegetation
description: A nocturnal seed-hoarder with an impressively long tail, this tiny rodent became an unlikely space explorer when five of its kind orbited the Moon 75 times aboard Apollo 17 in December 1972, with four surviving the historic journey.

name: Llano Pocket Gopher
region: Central Texas
habitat: Loamy soils suitable for digging
description: A master tunneler that constructs elaborate underground burrow systems with multiple chambers, food caches, and vertical corkscrew tunnels to evade predators. Males reach 18 cm in length and are so genetically distinct from their close relatives that scientists initially needed DNA sequencing to confirm their species status.

name: Lodgepole Chipmunk
region: California Sierra Nevada, Lake Tahoe area
habitat: Subalpine coniferous forests (lodgepole, Jeffrey, and sugar pine)
description: A striped mountain dweller that hibernates for five to six months and disperses fungi crucial to forest survival through its droppings. Despite weighing only 55 grams, it plays an outsized ecological role in maintaining Sierra Nevada ecosystems.

name: Long-eared Chipmunk
region: Central and northern Sierra Nevada, California and Nevada
habitat: High-elevation coniferous forests and alpine meadows
description: Sporting the longest ears of any chipmunk species, this bright red-brown rodent displays striking white ear patches and nine alternating dark and pale stripes running down its back. It can weigh up to 105 grams and hibernates for four months each winter in underground burrows.

name: Long-tailed Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Nevada, Utah) and Baja California
habitat: Desert scrubland and arid regions
description: This tiny desert rodent sports an exceptionally long tail relative to its body size, which it uses for balance while navigating rocky desert terrain. Despite its diminutive frame, it's remarkably adapted to arid environments where it forages for seeds and insects.

name: Mazama Pocket Gopher
region: Pacific Northwest (Washington, Oregon, Northern California)
habitat: Prairie grasslands with well-drained glacial soil
description: A diminutive burrower capable of turning over 3–7 tons of soil per acre annually, transforming prairie ecosystems and creating homes for countless other species with its powerful claws and tireless digging.

name: Meadow Jumping Mouse
region: Continental US from Atlantic coast to Great Plains, Canada to Alaska south to Georgia, Alabama, Arizona, and New Mexico
habitat: Moist grasslands and meadows with nearby streams, ponds, or marshes; high herbaceous cover with open areas preferred
description: A diminutive rodent with disproportionately large hind feet that can leap 2-3 feet in a single bound—roughly 12 times its body length. Before hibernation, this mouse balloons to 35 grams, nearly doubling its summer weight to survive months of dormancy.

name: Merriam's Chipmunk
region: Central and southern California, northern Baja California
habitat: Dry scrublands and chaparral in mountainous areas
description: This diminutive rodent uses a unique courtship ritual where females call for 10-15 minutes to attract males, who respond by leaping around before the entire mating process concludes in just 15 seconds. Armed with 22 teeth perfectly adapted for cracking seeds and nuts, it's a master of rapid-fire reproduction.

name: Merriam's Ground Squirrel
region: Western US (Oregon, Idaho, Nevada)
habitat: Arid sagebrush chaparral and grasslands
description: A cryptic grey squirrel that spends eight months of the year hibernating underground, emerging only in early spring to feed on seeds, roots, and insects before retreating again by August. Can only be reliably distinguished from similar species through genetic testing.

name: Merriam's Kangaroo Rat
region: Southwestern US, Baja California, northern Mexico
habitat: Desert scrub, sagebrush steppe, pinyon-juniper woodland, Joshua tree forests
description: A bipedal desert hopper with kangaroo-like hind feet and a distinctive hair-tufted tail that acts like an arrow's fletching to stabilize its movements. This nocturnal seed-hoarder avoids moonlit nights to escape predators, storing hundreds of seeds in underground chambers and extracting water from its food rather than drinking.

name: Merriam's Pocket Mouse
region: Southwest US and Northeast Mexico
habitat: Shortgrass prairie, desert scrub, and arid shrubland
description: This tiny nocturnal rodent survives up to four years without drinking water, extracting all moisture from seeds stored in its cheek pouches. At temperatures below 50°F, it enters a death-like torpor from which it mysteriously revives when warmed.

name: Mexican Fox Squirrel
region: Southeastern Arizona (Chiricahua Mountains)
habitat: Mixed pine-oak and conifer forests, riparian areas with cottonwoods
description: A surprisingly silent tree dweller weighing around 25 ounces, this squirrel forages year-round in forests maintained by natural fire and uses its charcoal tail frosted with white as a striking beacon through the canopy. When startled, it barks and chucks from safe perches rather than fleeing, preferring stealth over speed.

name: Mexican Ground Squirrel
region: Northern Mexico, Texas, Southeastern New Mexico
habitat: Flat, brushy, grassy areas with sandy or gravelly soil
description: A small burrowing rodent with nine distinctive rows of white spots on its back, this ground squirrel has evolved remarkable resistance to western diamondback rattlesnake venom through a specialized antihemorrhagic factor. Each individual maintains multiple burrows with up to five escape tunnels, allowing it to dart away from predators with impressive agility.

name: Mexican Spiny Pocket Mouse
region: Southern Texas and Mexico
habitat: Dry shrubland and scrubby uplands
description: A nocturnal mouse with a kangaroo-like leap that can cover 5 feet in a single second, armed with stiff spines mixed into its coat for protection. Uniquely dependent on water access, it stores seeds in cheek pouches and raises litters of up to eight young throughout the year.

name: Mohave Ground Squirrel
region: Mojave Desert, California
habitat: Joshua tree woodlands, creosote scrub, and desert scrublands
description: This nine-inch desert dweller enters a hibernation-like estivation state during dry months, with entire local populations vanishing during multi-year droughts—only to rebound when rains return. Males emit a distinctive high-pitched 'peep' alarm call that locals often mistake for a horned lark.

name: Morro Bay Kangaroo Rat
region: Central Coast of California
habitat: Fine sand dunes and coastal scrub
description: A tiny nocturnal hopper weighing just 60-80 grams, this rat's oversized hind legs and long tail let it leap like a miniature kangaroo across California's dunes. Restricted to a mere 2 km stretch of Morro Bay, it stands on the brink of extinction with fewer individuals surviving in the wild than many critically endangered species.

name: Mount Graham Red Squirrel
region: Arizona (Pinaleño Mountains)
habitat: High-elevation spruce-fir and mixed-conifer forests
description: This tiny 8-ounce squirrel was believed extinct until its miraculous rediscovery in the 1970s, and now survives in just the remote peaks of Arizona where it forages for fungi and conifer seeds. Unlike its red squirrel cousins, it lacks the characteristic white-fringed tail and sports rusty orange markings on its grayish-brown fur.

name: Mountain Beaver
region: Pacific Northwest and California mountains
habitat: Temperate rainforests and moist coniferous/deciduous forests
description: Despite being called a beaver, this nocturnal burrower is more closely related to squirrels and cannot concentrate urine—forcing it to consume massive amounts of water daily and restricting it to the wettest regions of North America. Known for devastating forest seedlings through bark-stripping and branch-cutting, it harbors the largest flea species on Earth, measuring up to 8 mm long.

name: Mountain Pocket Gopher
region: California and Nevada, particularly the Sierra Nevada
habitat: Mountain meadows, forest floors, and meadow edges
description: A tireless underground engineer that constructs tunnel systems spanning up to 2,000 square feet while rarely surfacing. This 91-gram rodent survives entirely on water extracted from plants and stores roots and bulbs in its elaborate burrow network.

name: Narrow-faced Kangaroo Rat
region: West-central California coastal mountains
habitat: Chaparral and sandy soils with oak or pine
description: This nimble rodent possesses a distinctly narrow face among its kangaroo rat cousins, allowing it to navigate the chaparral scrublands of coastal California with remarkable agility. Equipped with powerful hind legs for jumping and specialized cheek pouches for carrying seeds, it's perfectly adapted to life in sandy, drought-prone terrain.

name: Nelson's Pocket Mouse
region: Western Texas, southeastern New Mexico, central and northern Mexico
habitat: Desert with sparse scrubby vegetation, rocky slopes with cactus and creosote bush
description: A nimble nocturnal forager with fur-lined cheek pouches and distinctive dark-tipped spines on its rump, this desert dweller can pack seeds into its pouches while moving between plants on rocky slopes. Despite abundant numbers in late summer, only 14% survive to their first birthday.

name: Nine-banded Armadillo
region: Southeastern US, expanding northward to the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic
habitat: Grasslands, scrublands, rainforests, and open prairies
description: Encased in an impenetrable armor of bony plates, this insectivore can leap 3-4 feet straight into the air when frightened and hold its breath for up to six minutes while hunting underground. A single female can produce up to 56 young in her lifetime, driving the species' explosive expansion across North America.

name: North American Porcupine
region: Canada to northern Mexico, eastern North America to Alaska
habitat: Coniferous and mixed forests, shrublands, tundra
description: Armed with approximately 30,000 barbed quills covering its body, this slow-moving rodent relies on its formidable defense system rather than speed to survive. The only North American mammal to successfully live a solitary lifestyle among herbivores, it can remember complex mazes for up to 100 days.

name: Northern Flying Squirrel
region: Canada and northern United States, from Alaska to Nova Scotia, south to the Appalachian Mountains
habitat: Coniferous and mixed coniferous forests
description: A nocturnal glider that can soar up to 45 meters between trees by stretching a patagium membrane and making sharp 90-degree turns in mid-air before using its flat tail as a parachute to land safely on tree trunks.

name: Northern Idaho Ground Squirrel
region: Western-central Idaho (Adams and Valley Counties)
habitat: Dry rocky meadows with ponderosa pine and Douglas-fir forests
description: This critically endangered squirrel hibernates for 8 months straight and can construct three different types of burrows for specific purposes—nest burrows for breeding, auxiliary burrows for escape, and hibernation burrows for winter survival. Once widespread across 1,600 square kilometers, fewer than 2,000 individuals remain today.

name: Northern Pocket Gopher
region: Western US and Canadian provinces (Alberta, Saskatchewan, British Columbia, Manitoba)
habitat: Mountain meadows and lowlands with good soil, near streams
description: A subterranean master engineer that rarely surfaces, constructing tunnel systems extending hundreds of feet underground where it lives, stores food, and mates. Despite their small 60-160 gram frame, these burrowers significantly reshape their ecosystems by altering plant composition and affecting herbivore populations.

name: Olive-backed Pocket Mouse
region: Central Great Plains (Canada to Colorado)
habitat: Arid grasslands and semi-arid uplands
description: A nocturnal burrower that excavates tunnel systems reaching 6.5 feet deep and spanning nearly 10 feet across, storing hundreds of seeds in underground chambers to survive up to eight months of hibernation without emerging above ground.

name: Olympic Marmot
region: Olympic Peninsula, Washington
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, mountain slopes
description: This stocky alpine rodent displays the most pronounced sexual dimorphism of any marmot species, with males weighing 23% more than females. Before hibernating for eight months without eating, they nearly double their body weight and lose half of it by spring.

name: Ord's Kangaroo Rat
region: Great Plains and Great Basin, from southern Canada to central Mexico
habitat: Semiarid grasslands, shrublands, and sandy desert scrub
description: A nocturnal master of the desert with a fifth toe on its hind feet and a distinctive white-striped tail, this rat can make hundreds of seed caches to survive harsh conditions. Most water is obtained directly from seeds, allowing it to thrive in some of North America's most arid regions.

name: Pacific Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California coast
habitat: Coastal sand dunes and sage scrub near the Pacific Ocean
description: Believed extinct for nearly 20 years before its miraculous rediscovery in 1993, this tiny hibernator weighs less than a third of an ounce yet survives California's harsh coastal climate by storing seeds in fur-lined cheek pouches up to 12 inches long.

name: Pale Kangaroo Mouse
region: Central Nevada and eastern California deserts
habitat: Sand dunes and sandy desert floors of the Great Basin
description: A nocturnal hopper weighing less than half an ounce, this bipedal rodent avoids moonlight and caches seeds across multiple hiding spots to outwit competing desert scavengers. Known to derive all its water from insects rather than drinking free water.

name: Palmer's Chipmunk
region: Southern Nevada (Spring Mountains)
habitat: High-altitude temperate forests with pinyon pine, juniper, fir, and bristlecone pine
description: A diminutive striped rodent weighing barely 60 grams that survives Nevada's harsh winters by caching ponderosa pine seeds and emerging on warm days to raid its own underground pantries. Found only in the remote Spring Mountains, this endangered chipmunk is losing ground to campground expansion and Las Vegas sprawl.

name: Panamint Chipmunk
region: Southeast California and southwest Nevada
habitat: Pinyon pine-juniper woodlands, bushes, boulders, and cliffs
description: A nimble desert dweller that navigates rocky cliffs and canyon walls with ease, serving as a vital food source for raptors, coyotes, and bobcats across the arid southwest. Despite its small size, it thrives in harsh pinyon-juniper environments where few other small mammals persist.

name: Panamint Kangaroo Rat
region: Eastern California and western Nevada (Mojave Desert)
habitat: Great Basin bush desert, sandy mounds with brush clumps at high elevations
description: A nocturnal desert hopper with a tail 140% longer than its body, equipped with fur-lined cheek pouches and the remarkable ability to survive indefinitely on metabolic water extracted from seeds, producing only a single drop of urine every 1–2 hours.

name: Piute Ground Squirrel
region: Great Basin region of western US (California, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah, Washington)
habitat: Great Basin scrublands and arid regions
description: A nimble burrower endemic to the Great Basin, this small squirrel is perfectly adapted to arid environments and serves as a key food source for the region's raptors and predators.

name: Plains Pocket Gopher
region: Great Plains (Manitoba to Texas)
habitat: Grasslands and agricultural land with sandy, friable soils
description: A master tunneler that excavates up to 2,059 cm of new burrows per week, spending 72% of its time underground in a solitary lifestyle guided by extraordinary sensitivity to soil vibrations. Despite being dismissed as pests, these rodents are vital ecosystem engineers that improve soil aeration, drainage, and plant diversity across the Great Plains.

name: Plains Pocket Mouse
region: Great Plains and Southwest, from Minnesota and North Dakota to Texas and northern Mexico
habitat: Sandy soil areas with Spanish bayonet and prickly pear plants
description: A tiny rodent barely 5 inches long that carries seeds in specialized cheek pouches, capable of storing enough foraged food to survive in arid grasslands where other mammals struggle.

name: Red-tailed Chipmunk
region: Pacific Northwest and Northern Rockies (British Columbia, Alberta, Washington, Idaho, Montana)
habitat: Coniferous forests and woodland edges at high elevations (2,360-7,870 ft)
description: A bushy-tailed mountain dweller weighing barely 2 ounces that stores seeds in expandable cheek pouches and enters torpor during harsh winters rather than full hibernation. Its distinctive pinkish-buff and orange-brown coloring makes it nearly impossible to distinguish from the yellow-pine chipmunk without skeletal examination.

name: Richardson's Ground Squirrel
region: Northern US (North Dakota, Montana) and western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan)
habitat: Short grass prairies and grasslands; adapts to suburban areas
description: Named for its constantly trembling tail that earns it the nickname "flickertail," this ground squirrel can nearly triple its weight from 250g to 750g before hibernation. Notable for its cannibalistic tendencies and the ability to communicate through both audible whistles and ultrasonic alarm calls to warn colony mates of approaching predators.

name: Rio Grande Ground Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Texas and New Mexico), northeastern Mexico
habitat: Arid and semi-arid grasslands
description: Once classified as a subspecies of the Mexican ground squirrel, genetic analysis revealed this burrowing rodent was distinct enough to warrant its own genus—Ictidomys—reshaping our understanding of ground squirrel evolution.

name: Rock Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern United States and Mexico
habitat: Rocky desert outcrops
description: A nocturnal desert dweller that has evolved a striking example of adaptive melanism, with dark-colored populations perfectly matching black volcanic rock formations while lighter cousins blend seamlessly into tan desert stone. The same dark coat has evolved independently in separate populations through entirely different genetic mutations, a remarkable case of convergent evolution.

name: Rock Squirrel
region: Southwestern US and Mexico (Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico, West Texas, Oklahoma panhandle)
habitat: Rocky mountains, canyon walls, cliffs, and steep rocky hills
description: One of the largest ground squirrels in North America, reaching up to 21 inches in length, with the remarkable ability to survive up to 100 days without water. These social burrowers can carry up to 62 acorns in their cheek pouches and will fearlessly throw debris at approaching snakes.

name: Round-tailed Ground Squirrel
region: Southwestern US and Northwestern Mexico
habitat: Desert regions with loose soil, mesquite trees, and creosote bushes
description: This tiny desert burrower weighs merely 125 grams and survives the harshest conditions by choosing foods with 80% water content, never needing a drink. When threatened by snakes, it performs a distinctive tail-wagging display and even kicks dirt at its predators.

name: San Bernardino Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California (San Bernardino and Riverside counties)
habitat: Sandy alluvial scrub with chaparral and coastal sage scrub
description: A four-toed desert dweller with an extraordinarily compressed range: once spanning 320,000 acres, its habitat has shrunk to just 3,247 acres by 1998. These tiny rodents can leap across sandy floodplains using their oversized hind feet and balancing tail, but urban development and flood control projects now threaten their survival.

name: San Diego Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California and northern Baja California
habitat: Desert scrub, rocky areas with herbaceous vegetation
description: A nocturnal forager equipped with fur-lined cheek pouches that can survive indefinitely without drinking water by extracting moisture from seeds and metabolic processes. Males defend territories spanning nearly an acre while females patrol smaller ranges of just over half an acre.

name: San Joaquin Antelope Squirrel
region: San Joaquin Valley, California
habitat: Sandy grasslands with sparse vegetation; Carrizo Plain
description: This tiny squirrel can survive at least 7 months without water in the shade and cleverly uses the white underside of its tail as a predator-deceiving lure, flicking it to mimic thistledown blowing in the wind. Once abundant across the San Joaquin Valley, fewer than 1 per hectare remain today due to agricultural expansion.

name: San Joaquin Pocket Mouse
region: California (Central Valley, Sierra Nevada foothills, Mojave Desert)
habitat: Desert and semi-desert grasslands with creosote bush and Joshua tree
description: A tiny desert rodent equipped with fur-lined cheek pouches that can carry seeds back to its burrow for storage during lean seasons. Despite weighing mere ounces, it may enter a dormant state called torpor to survive harsh winters.

name: Sand Hills Pocket Gopher
region: Great Plains (Wyoming, Colorado, South Dakota, Nebraska)
habitat: Sand Hills grasslands, Mississippi basin
description: A master tunneler that spends most of its life underground, this pocket gopher was long debated by scientists before genetic evidence confirmed it as a distinct species rather than a regional variant of the plains pocket gopher.

name: Silky Pocket Mouse
region: Southwest US and northern/central Mexico
habitat: Arid and semiarid grasslands, sandy areas, shrublands with yucca and cactus
description: The smallest pocket mouse in its family, this nocturnal forager can collect and store an entire 25-gram pile of seeds—enough to sustain itself for 10 days—in a single night. When temperatures drop below freezing, it enters short periods of torpor and survives on its meticulously organized underground seed caches.

name: Siskiyou Chipmunk
region: Northern California and central Oregon
habitat: Siskiyou Mountains and forested areas between the Klamath and Rogue Rivers
description: This striped rodent sports a distinctive pattern of five dark brown and four gray stripes running down its back, with the central stripe appearing almost black. Most active during early evening hours, it communicates with distinctive single-syllable calls spaced evenly apart.

name: Sonoma Chipmunk
region: Northwestern California (Sonoma and Marin counties)
habitat: Coniferous forests and chaparral, from sea level to 5,900 feet
description: These tiny striped rodents weigh less than half an ounce yet produce alarm calls so distinct they're recognized across chipmunk species, with females working overtime as protective sentries for their young. Masters of camouflage, their barely-demarcated back stripes blur seamlessly into chaparral habitat while they cache seeds in oversized cheek pouches.

name: Southeastern Pocket Gopher
region: Southeastern US (Alabama, Georgia, Florida)
habitat: Sandy pine woodlands and scrubland with longleaf pine and turkey oak
description: A master underground architect that creates elaborate burrow systems with spiral staircases, pushing up distinctive fan-shaped mounds as it digs. Despite producing only an average of two offspring per year, this industrious burrower thrives throughout the Southeast and may actually improve soil fertility through its excavations.

name: Southern Flying Squirrel
region: Eastern North America, from southeastern Canada to Florida; disjunct populations in Mexican highlands
habitat: Deciduous and mixed forests with hickory, beech, oak, maple, and poplar trees
description: This nocturnal glider extends a furry membrane between its limbs to descend at 30-40 degree angles, making precise 90-degree turns mid-air before raising its flattened tail to brake and land safely. Despite being clumsy on the ground, it can return to its nest from up to a kilometer away using spatial memory alone.

name: Southern Idaho Ground Squirrel
region: Southwestern Idaho
habitat: Rolling hills, basins, and flats at moderate elevation
description: Found only in a 30-by-70 kilometer range of southwestern Idaho, this ground squirrel weighs between 120 and 290 grams and exhibits notable sexual dimorphism with males significantly larger than females. Once considered the same species as its northern cousin, this vulnerable rodent inhabits the unique terrain bounded by the Payette and Snake rivers.

name: Southern Pocket Gopher
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico) and Mexico
habitat: High altitude grassland and shrubland, desert grassland and woodland
description: A prolific burrower that creates distinctive mounds of excavated soil across grasslands, this rodent can produce litters of up to ten young in a single breeding season. Active year-round without hibernation, it shares its underground tunnels with other species and serves as prey for owls, hawks, coyotes, and badgers.

name: Southwestern Red Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona)
habitat: High-altitude mixed coniferous and spruce-fir forests
description: A tree-dwelling survivor of the last ice age, this species has remained isolated in mountain refuges for over 130,000 years with virtually no genetic exchange between populations. Its scattered populations face an uncertain future as habitat fragmentation threatens to drive them toward extinction.

name: Spiny Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Nevada) and Baja California
habitat: Rocky desert landscapes and desert islands
description: A nocturnal desert dweller weighing just 0.5 ounces, distinguished by flexible spines running down its back that help it navigate rough, rocky terrain. Its tail grows to 126% the length of its body and head combined, aiding balance in the harsh desert environment.

name: Spotted Ground Squirrel
region: Central and western US (South Dakota to Texas), Mexico
habitat: Sandy arid regions, dunes, sparse grasslands
description: One of North America's tiniest squirrels, this spotted burrower enters hibernation for up to 10 months per year and employs 7 distinct alert postures to warn companions of danger. Males engage in frenzied mating displays, darting in and out of burrows in rapid succession.

name: Stephens' Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California, primarily western Riverside County
habitat: Sparsely vegetated temperate grassland with gravelly soils
description: This medium-sized rodent's tail is 1.45 times longer than its body, and it creates a keystone effect on its ecosystem by clearing vegetation patches and dispersing seeds through caching, increasing plant diversity around its burrows.

name: Strecker's Pocket Gopher
region: Texas
habitat: Underground burrows in grasslands and prairies
description: A burrowing rodent that was long mistaken for its close relative until chromosomal analysis revealed it as a distinct species. Named after American herpetologist John Kern Strecker, this pocket gopher spends most of its life underground, using powerful claws to excavate elaborate tunnel systems across Texas grasslands.

name: Texas Antelope Squirrel
region: Western Texas, south-central New Mexico, and northern Mexico
habitat: Desert burrows and rock crevices near bushes and shrubs
description: This small desert dweller can consume so much prickly pear cactus fruit that its flesh turns purple, and remarkably remains active year-round without hibernating despite harsh desert conditions.

name: Texas Kangaroo Rat
region: North-central Texas and Oklahoma
habitat: Clay-loam prairie with mesquite and lotebush brush, prairie mounds
description: This relatively large kangaroo rat stores seeds and vegetation in its cheek pouches and can survive on bare ground and prairie mounds without brush, making it a surprisingly adaptable rodent despite its vulnerable status across only 13 Texas counties.

name: Texas Pocket Gopher
region: Southern Texas and northeastern Mexico
habitat: Sandy soils and sand drifts, including coastal islands
description: An underground specialist that constructs burrow systems stretching nearly 100 feet, this rodent pulls plant roots down into its tunnels to avoid surface predators and even practices coprophagy to maximize nutrient extraction.

name: Thirteen-lined Ground Squirrel
region: Central and northern North America grasslands and prairies
habitat: Grasslands and prairies
description: This striped burrower can survive over six months in hibernation without food or water, slowing its breathing from 200 breaths per minute to just one breath every five minutes. Known for its distinctive upright posture and bird-like alarm trill, it dives into burrows up to 20 feet long at the first sign of danger.

name: Tipton Kangaroo Rat
region: Central California (Kern and Tulare Counties)
habitat: Ground burrows in grasslands and scrublands
description: A diminutive desert hopper weighing just 35-38 grams, this creature compensates for its tiny forefeet with exceptionally oversized hind legs and a 125mm tail used for balance during explosive leaps. Known to survive on a diet of seeds with only occasional insects, it remains one of California's most critically endangered rodents.

name: Townsend's Chipmunk
region: Pacific Northwest (southwestern British Columbia through western Washington and Oregon)
habitat: Pacific Northwest forests with dense shrubbery
description: A large chipmunk reaching 14 inches from nose to tail, identifiable by its grayish-and-reddish tail and distinctive brown coloration. In mild climates, this omnivorous forager remains active year-round, switching from summer berries to acorns and conifer seeds as seasons change.

name: Townsend's Ground Squirrel
region: Great Basin and Columbia Plateau (Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Utah, Nevada, California)
habitat: High desert shrublands, arid grasslands, and sagebrush-grasslands
description: A desert burrower that enters dormancy for 7.5 to 9 months each year, emerging in late winter to breed and forage. Critical prey for ferruginous hawks and prairie falcons across the Great Basin, with population densities fluctuating wildly from 3 to 331 individuals per hectare depending on habitat conditions.

name: Townsend's Pocket Gopher
region: Northwestern US (Idaho, Oregon, Nevada, California)
habitat: Deep, moist soils near rivers and lakes, irrigated cropland
description: A powerful underground excavator that can measure up to 11 inches long and weigh nearly a pound, equipped with massive digging claws and fur-lined cheek pouches. This solitary burrower spends almost its entire adult life underground, leaving behind telltale mounds of soil across the landscape.

name: Uinta Chipmunk
region: Western United States (Utah, Arizona, Nevada, California, Wyoming, Colorado)
habitat: Montane and subalpine pine and fir forests
description: A nimble forest dweller that can emit bursts of sharp "chip" sounds lasting up to 15 minutes from exposed perches. Despite their small 67-gram frame, these solitary chipmunks fiercely defend territories spanning up to 12 acres in high mountain elevations.

name: Uinta Ground Squirrel
region: Northern and central Utah, eastern Idaho, southwestern Montana, and western Wyoming
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, pastures, and shrub-steppe
description: Known locally as a "chisler," this ground squirrel emerges from hibernation weighing just 7.4 ounces and nearly doubles its weight before retreating underground again—spending less than half the year awake. Despite living in colonies, adults are aggressively territorial and communicate through six distinct vocalizations to warn of predators or assert dominance.

name: Utah Prairie Dog
region: South-central Utah
habitat: Semi-arid grasslands and swale areas with herbaceous vegetation
description: The smallest prairie dog species, these highly social rodents engineer elaborate underground towns that transform landscapes and provide homes for countless other species. Once numbering 95,000 individuals in 1920, their population plummeted 87% by the 1970s due to habitat destruction and human persecution.

name: Virginia Opossum
region: Continental US and southern Canada, expanding northward from Maryland to Maine, Ontario, and British Columbia
habitat: Urban and suburban areas, forests, and mixed terrain near food sources
description: North America's only marsupial north of Mexico, equipped with 50 teeth—more than any other land mammal on the continent—and an opposable thumb on its hind feet for gripping. When threatened, it famously plays dead with such conviction that its heart rate drops by half and breathing becomes nearly undetectable.

name: Washington Ground Squirrel
region: Pacific Northwest (Washington and Oregon)
habitat: Sagebrush and grassland in the Columbia River Basin
description: This burrowing rodent hibernates for 7–8 months annually and can disperse over 3.5 kilometers from its birthplace, with juvenile males showing remarkable survival rates higher than their sedentary siblings.

name: Western Gray Squirrel
region: Western coast of the United States and Mexico, from Washington to Baja California
habitat: Coniferous and oak forests, arboreal tree dweller up to 2,000 m elevation
description: A shy forest acrobat weighing less than a kilogram with a distinctive silver-gray coat and perpetually bushy tail curved in an 'S' shape. Despite being the largest native tree squirrel on the western coast, it struggles to compete with introduced species and can take six months or longer to fledge its young.

name: White-eared Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California mountains
habitat: High-elevation pine forests and chaparral
description: A tiny mountain dweller named for the distinctive white-edged ears adorning its yellowish-brown fur, this pocket mouse reaches only 155 mm in length and inhabits pine forests above 4,900 feet in the San Bernardino and Tehachapi Mountains.

name: White-tailed Antelope Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Oregon to New Mexico) and Baja California
habitat: Arid desert regions and shrublands
description: This desert sprinter is surprisingly carnivorous, hunting lizards and rodents despite being a ground squirrel. Active during the day to avoid nighttime predators, it covers up to 4 acres daily across some of the harshest terrain in North America.

name: White-tailed Prairie Dog
region: Western Wyoming, western Colorado, eastern Utah, southern Montana
habitat: High-elevation grasslands and prairie (5,000-10,000 feet)
description: Colonial herbivores that live in complex family units and communicate through barks and visual signals, these tan-brown rodents have mysteriously declined to occupy just 8% of their original range despite conservation efforts.

name: Woodland Jumping Mouse
region: Northeastern North America
habitat: Cool, moist boreal woodlands with spruce-fir and hemlock, near streams and meadows
description: A diminutive rodent capable of leaping up to 10 feet using its extraordinarily powerful hind legs and lengthy tail, which comprises 60% of its body length. During hibernation, this mouse's body temperature plummets from 98.6°F to 36°F, and only one in three mice survives the winter.

name: Wyoming Ground Squirrel
region: Northwestern United States
habitat: Grasslands and open meadows
description: A small burrowing rodent endemic to the Pacific Northwest, identifiable by its elegant coloring and pale color variants that resemble cream-colored mutations found in laboratory rats.

name: Wyoming Pocket Gopher
region: Southern Wyoming
habitat: Flat, well-drained areas with greasewood and saltbush
description: The smallest member of its genus, this pocket gopher weighs just 44-72 grams yet possesses disproportionately powerful digging claws and cheek pouches that extend 44mm back from its snout for carrying food through narrow underground tunnels.

name: Yellow-bellied Marmot
region: Rocky Mountains, Sierra Nevada, Great Basin; southwestern Canada to northern New Mexico
habitat: Alpine meadows, talus fields, and open rocky areas above 2,000 meters
description: This rotund ground squirrel spends 80% of its life underground, hibernating for eight months straight in burrows up to 23 feet deep. Known as the "whistle pig" for its distinctive alarm calls that warn colonies of approaching predators.

name: Yellow-cheeked Chipmunk
region: Northern California coast
habitat: Coastal coniferous forests
description: The largest chipmunk in its genus, this secretive rodent emits a distinctive low-pitched "chuck-chuck" call and can grow up to 11.7 inches long. Despite its limited range of just 20,000 square kilometers along the California coast, its population remains steady and untroubled by threats.

name: Yellow-faced Pocket Gopher
region: Southwestern US and Northern Mexico
habitat: Shortgrass prairies with deep sandy or silty soils
description: An industrious burrower that excavates tunnel systems averaging 75.8 meters in length, pulling entire plants into its underground network by their roots. Males continue growing throughout their lives, eventually becoming significantly larger than females.

name: Yellow-pine Chipmunk
region: Western North America, parts of Canada and the United States
habitat: Brush-covered areas and coniferous forests at high elevation
description: This industrious rodent defies typical mammalian trends by having females larger than males, and survives harsh winters entirely on cached seeds gathered during summer—storing food up to 4.9 meters apart to maximize survival odds through hibernation.
